G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 28A, G.L..proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Emily Johnson (“Mother”), and respectfully complains and alleges as follows in support of her Complaint for Modification of a prior custody judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the Court’s equitable powers:

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has **continuing jurisdiction** over custody, visitation, and parenting-time matters concerning Sophia Smith pursuant to:

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: This Court has **continuing jurisdiction** over custody, visitation, and parenting-time matters concerning Sophia Smith pursuant to:

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has **continuing jurisdiction** over custody, visitation, and parenting-time matters concerning Sophia Smith pursuant to:

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).proposition: The Court’s **inherent equity jurisdiction** over the welfare of minor children. See *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses statutory and common‑law standards governing custody, parental fitness, and the Commonwealth’s parens patriae role, but it does so within the framework of specific Massachusetts statutes (G.L. c. 119, c. 201, c. 210). It does not describe or ground the decision in the Court’s inherent equity jurisdiction over the welfare of minors, nor does it invoke such inherent equitable power as the basis for adjudicating custody. Accordingly, this case is not direct authority for the specific proposition about inherent equity jurisdiction.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection. In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related. … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’ ”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The 2019 Custody Judgment was based upon the circumstances then existing and the Court’s determination of the **best interests of the child** under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related case law.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The 2019 Custody Judgment was based upon the circumstances then existing and the Court’s determination of the **best interests of the child** under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related case law. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711–12 (1985) (best interests standard governs custody); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265 (2001).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas directly interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and expressly states that the words “upon cause shown” in the removal statute mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and then explains that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern. Although the case is a removal/custody case rather than a post-2019 judgment case, it is proper authority for the general proposition that Massachusetts custody determinations are governed by a best-interests-of-the-child standard under the relevant divorce and custody statutes.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711–12 (1985) (best interests standard governs custody); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: Rosenthal deals with modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and removal under § 30, and it applies a best-interests analysis in that context. The proposition concerns an original custody judgment being based on then-existing circumstances and the best interests of the child under § 31. Rosenthal neither cites § 31 nor discusses the statutory framework for initial custody determinations; it addresses standards for modification and relocation, so it does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition stated.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 624\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified when there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and modification is necessary in the **best interests of the child**.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 624\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly addresses how changes to a custody judgment must be made and ties that to the statutory modification mechanism under G.L. c. 208, § 28, which incorporates the Massachusetts standard of a material and substantial change in circumstances and best interests of the child. By holding that any change in custody must proceed by complaint for modification under § 28, the court affirms that custody changes are governed by that modification standard, which includes both elements stated in the proposition.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 624\u2.relevant_excerpt: "A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan."

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified when there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and modification is necessary in the **best interests of the child**.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence focused on relocation under the paternity statute and does not set out the general Massachusetts standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting-time order. It discusses best interests and stability, but not the requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances as the governing test for modification. Without language addressing modification standards, this case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (“If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement …”).

Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.raw_text: Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 156, 159–60 (2001)
Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified when there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and modification is necessary in the **best interests of the child**.
Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.support_reasoning: The case is a child-support modification case, not a custody or parenting-time case, but the court explicitly states that the governing Massachusetts statute for support modification (G.L. c. 208, § 28) requires analysis of both changed circumstances and the best interests of the children. That same statute also governs custody and parenting-time modifications, which are subject to the same two-part standard. Thus, while the context is support rather than custody, the opinion does affirm the quoted legal principle under Massachusetts law.
Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 15.relevant_excerpt: “The statute governing support modification requires an analysis of both the changed circumstances of the parties and the best interests of the children. See G. L. c. 208, § 28.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The paramount consideration in any modification of custody or parenting time is the **best interests of the child**. G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ as the governing standard in custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and characterizes it as the paramount consideration in custody matters. While the case is a first-instance custody determination rather than a post-judgment modification, the court cites and reaffirms the long-standing rule that in custody disputes “the best interests of the child” are always the paramount concern, which is the same principle applied in modification proceedings under G.L. c. 208, § 31. Thus it is proper authority for the proposition that best interests are paramount in any custody/parenting-time change.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); … DeFerrari v. DeFerrari, 220 Mass. 38, 41 (1914) (custody award is subject to revision ‘as the best interests of the child may demand’).”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: In determining best interests, the Court considers, among other things:
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses what factors must be considered in determining the child’s best interests in custody, emphasizing that the court must consider the impact of domestic violence and make explicit findings about its effect on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award. While the quoted proposition is incomplete (“among other things”), Vaughn clearly stands for the principle that, in best-interests determinations, the court must consider domestic violence and its effects as a required factor. Thus it supports the general idea that multiple factors, including domestic violence, are part of the best-interests analysis.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: In determining best interests, the Court considers, among other things:
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses what a judge must consider in determining a child’s best interests in an adoption/custody context. It explains that the judge properly weighed multiple factors, including competing adoption plans, stability, developmental needs, sibling relationships, and available supports, and emphasizes that best interests is a flexible standard allowing consideration of a wide range of permissible evidence. This aligns with the proposition that the court considers various factors in making a best-interests determination.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). … [I]n child custody cases the best interests standard mandated by G. L. c. 210, § 3, is “a flexible one,” and the weight to be accorded its several considerations, including the importance of sibling relations, “will vary with the circumstances.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts recognize that when a significant change in a parent’s circumstances undermines the child’s safety or welfare, a **reallocation of physical custody** to the more capable parent is appropriate. See, e.g.:
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.support_reasoning: The case concerns the standard for *removal* of children from Massachusetts where parents share joint physical and legal custody, not reallocation of physical custody between parents based on changed circumstances affecting the child’s safety or welfare. The Probate and Family Court in fact *continued* shared physical custody and denied both parents’ requests for sole physical custody; the SJC affirmed that decision and focused on the best-interests analysis for relocation, not on transferring physical custody. Thus, Mason v. Coleman does not stand for the proposition that a significant change in circumstances warrants reallocation of physical custody to the more capable parent.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.relevant_excerpt: “The judge determined that the father’s move to Nashua did not provide ground for the relief requested by the mother, and the judge did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody…. We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children. The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts recognize that when a significant change in a parent’s circumstances undermines the child’s safety or welfare, a **reallocation of physical custody** to the more capable parent is appropriate. See, e.g.:
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the general best‑interests standard for initial custody determinations and criticizes awarding custody as a punishment for a parent’s misconduct. It orders a remand for further findings on the comparative parental environments but does not discuss a post‑judgment modification standard, changed circumstances, or expressly approve reallocation of physical custody following a significant change in a parent’s circumstances. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about reallocation upon changed circumstances undermining the child’s safety or welfare.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’ … ‘Custody is not a prize . . . .’”

App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct-appeal custody decision made in the original divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification based on a subsequent, ‘significant change’ in a parent’s circumstances. The court applies the general ‘best interests of the children’ standard to affirm an initial award of sole custody to the mother and a limitation on the father’s visitation; it does not discuss reallocation of physical custody in response to later‑arising circumstances undermining safety or welfare. Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 872–73 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: To the extent the original judgment may have arisen in a non-marital context, the same standards apply under G.L. c. 209C, § 20, which authorizes modification of judgments concerning custody and visitation of children born outside of marriage, upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the **best interests of the child**. See *Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 872–73 (2006).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with post-divorce removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, in the context of married parents who are now divorced. It does not cite or discuss G.L. c. 209C, § 20, nor does it address standards for modifying custody or visitation judgments for children born outside marriage. While it reaffirms that modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination of the best interests of the children, it does so under c. 208, not under c. 209C or in a non-marital context, so it cannot be authority for the proposition that “the same standards apply” under c. 209C, § 20.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: Grant such further and other relief as the Court deems just and proper to protect the **best interests of the child**, including but not limited to orders under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, and, where applicable, G.L. c. 209C, § 20.
